fields.headline: What's hot
fields.bodyText: Chateau living Chateau de Lartigolle, a 15th-century property perched on the highest point of the Gers region in south-west France, is a new addition to the French holiday home market. With six large bedrooms in the main chateau, a studio that can be used as a kids' dorm and two smaller rooms in the wing, it can sleep up to 16 adults plus children. There's a pool, tennis court and barbecue on site, and lakes, forests and riding stables nearby. · Chateau de Lartigolle (00 33 5 62 63 26 27; lartigolle.com) £4,000 per week; guests can self-cater or pay extra for meals. Old meets new Radisson Edwardian is converting the Free Trade Hall - former home of the Hallé Symphony Orchestra - in Manchester into its first hotel outside London. The historic building houses the Opus One restaurant, an elaborate room with antique gold wall coverings, black lacquered woodwork and red chandeliers; the 263 bedrooms and a second restaurant, Alto Terrace, are housed in a modern 16-storey tower behind the hall. · Radisson Edwardian (0161 835 9929, radisson edwardian.com/manchester). Opening offer: £100 double, room only, exc VAT. Opens June.
